Works for me, but not for you

Page Summaries: This page features a title page for a presentation on 'Machine Learning Operations for Accelerator Control' by Tia Miceli from the Accelerator AI/ML Group, Accelerator Controls Department, FNAL, under the institution Fermi Research Alliance, LLC. It also mentions that the presentation was part of the EPICS Collaboration Meeting held from 24-28 April 2023. The page includes an aerial image of the Fermilab facility.

This page discusses the necessity of a sustainable approach to developing, deploying, monitoring, and servicing machine learning applications for accelerators. Key challenges highlighted include the knowledge gap when the sole knowledgeable person leaves, the reproducibility problem in deep learning, and issues related to life-cycle handling of ML applications.

The page underscores the importance of sustainable practices in the development, deployment, monitoring, and servicing of machine learning applications specifically for accelerators. It points out critical issues such as the loss of knowledgeable personnel, the reproducibility problem in deep learning, and managing the life cycle of applications, suggesting solutions like self-documenting procedures, automated bookkeeping, and automated updates.
This page addresses the reproducibility problem in AI and ML, highlighting common issues and best practices to mitigate them.

This page addresses the reproducibility problem in AI/ML, providing a quote on the difficulty of reproducing model weights, and presents a table categorizing typical and tricky issues with suggested mitigating best practices.

The page discusses the challenges and solutions relating to serving an AI controller model. It highlights the risks of simply deploying a model without proper precautions, such as data drift and system failures, and proposes MLOps as a solution for monitoring and automating model retraining and deployment.

The page is a presentation slide discussing the deployment of AI/ML capabilities for operations, highlighting the need for additional engineering and stewardship activities such as data ingestion, model inference serving, and prediction streaming.

This page presents a diagram of the workflow for MLOps (Machine Learning Operations), outlining the different stages involved: Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations.

This page presents a diagram detailing the workflow for MLOps in accelerator control. The workflow includes stages such as Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations.

This page presents a diagram illustrating the workflow for MLOps in the context of accelerator control. It emphasizes the steps involved in Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations, detailing tasks such as data collection, labeling, versioning, and development interactions.

This page presents a workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. The workflow covers stages like Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. It includes steps such as data collection, preparation, model training, and testing.

This page presents a workflow for MLOps highlighting the stages involved in data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations. It includes standardized practices for data logging and filtering, a dataset management system, and common tools for model development.

This page presents a workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) specifically for accelerator control. It outlines the steps involved in data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations. Tools and systems like standardized data formats, MLFillter, and VC are also highlighted.

This page describes the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. It covers various stages such as Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. It also highlights the use of standardized tools and systems for data handling, model development, and system operations.

This page provides a graphical representation of the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps). It includes steps for data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations with accompanying descriptions of standardized tools and systems utilized in the process.

This page provides a visual representation of the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. It highlights the key phases of Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, and Operations Development, detailing the tasks involved in each phase. Additionally, there are notes on standardized acceleration data, the use of common tools, interfaces for ML engineers, and model registry details.

This page provides an overview of the workflow for MLOps, outlining the steps involved in Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. It includes a diagram that visually represents these processes and lists standardized tools and interfaces used in the workflow.

This diagram illustrates the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) used in accelerator control systems, detailing the processes of data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations. It highlights the interfaces, tools, and server specifications required to effectively manage and deploy ML models.

This page presents a detailed workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in an accelerator control context. It describes the distinct phases including Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations, outlining the processes and tools involved in each phase to facilitate automation and system efficiency.

This page discusses the expansion of DevOps into Machine Learning Operations (MLOps). It highlights the integration and streamlining of software development and deployment, emphasizing agile practices and continuous integration/continuous delivery (CI/CD). It also includes a comparison of Software Product Development Models (Waterfall vs. Agile).

This page outlines the infrastructure needed for implementing machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator controls. It highlights necessary components such as Data Management, Model Development, Operations Development, System Operations, and Common Tools.

The page outlines Fermilab's efforts to build out their accelerator control systems through MLOps. It covers their integration requirements for the ACORN 2020-2029 control system, collaborations with other accelerator laboratories like SLAC, CERN, and BNL, and the open source toolset R&D on a Kubernetes cluster. The page also mentions data management and model development tools, as well as discussions about licensing with the Tech Transfer Office.
The page discusses the efforts of Fermilab Accelerator Controls AI/ML Group in designing their MLOps infrastructure and is seeking feedback on workflows, specifically what worked and what didn't.

This page announces the 4th ICFA Beam Dynamics Mini-Workshop on Machine Learning Applications for Particle Accelerators, which will be held from 5–8 March 2024 in Gyeongju, Republic of Korea. The announcement includes a nighttime image of a traditional Korean pavilion and mentions the institutions involved: Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL) and POSTECH.
